statement.tex: %text Let $f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be defined as $f(x)=10x+7$. Find the function $g:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $gof=fog=I_R$ %

step.context: %text For any function $f$ to be invertible, it must be? %
step.reason: %text If a function $f$ is invertible, it must be one-one and onto and conversely, if $f$ is one-one and onto, then it must be invertible. %

step.context: %text If $f(x)$ is one-one, what does $f(x_1)=f(x_2)$ imply? %
step.reason: %text If $f(x)$ is a one-one function then, % \begin{align} f(x_1)=f(x_2) &\implies x_1=x_2 \\ x_1=x_2 &\implies f(x_1)=f(x_2) \end{align}

step.context: %text If $f(x)$ is onto, what does $f(x)=y$ imply? %
step.tex: %text That $\forall$ y $\in \mathbb{R}$, there exists an $x \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x)=y$ %
step.reason: %text A function $f:X\rightarrow Y$ is said to be onto (or surjective), if every element in $Y$ is the image of some element in $X$, i.e. for every $y\in Y$, there exists an element $x\in X$ such that $f(x)=y$. %
